title: Momentum motion and force - p-vs-t graph for cart

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A lab cart of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is free to move to the left or right on a straight, horizontal track, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, with negligible friction in the axles of the cart’s wheels. The cart is at rest at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. A single, horizontal applied force, which may or may not vary over time, is then exerted on the cart. Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shows the resulting momentum of the cart as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, where the positive direction is taken to be toward the right. The momentum reaches a maximum of <math alttext="p sub maximum" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> at <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

(a) The dots in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> represent the cart at times <math alttext="t equals 0.9, t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.9</mn><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="t equals 1.1 t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.1</mn><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, as indicated. On each dot, draw and label the forces (not components) exerted on the cart at the indicated time. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the appropriate dot.
Note: The relative lengths of the arrows should reflect the relative magnitudes of the forces.
